children.name: stop drinking a2
children.definition: give up drinking/stop drinking to stop drinking anything alcoholic, especially because it is becoming a problem:cai rượu
examples: sam’s been told that unless he stops drinking, he could be dead within a year.
i didn’t realize i had a problem until i tried to give up drinking but couldn’t.

children.name: be on the wagon x
children.definition: be on the wagon informal no longer drink alcohol, or to have stopped drinking alcohol for a short time: đang cai rượu
examples: do you want a beer, harry, or are you still on the wagon?
i thought you were on the wagon!
he was on the wagon for ten years, when he was living in connecticut.

children.name: drunk b2
children.definition: drunk sb who is drunk has drunk too muchalcoholand cannot think clearly or behave sensibly:say
examples: she was so drunk she could hardly stand up.
gary was too drunk to remember what had happened that night.
i'd had a couple of glasses of wine but i certainly wasn't drunk.

children.name: have had too much to drink u
children.definition: have had too much to drink/ have had one too many  to have drunk too much alcohol so that you feel very drunk or sick:uống quá nhiều, quá chén
examples: i’d better take tanya home - she’s had too much to drink.
he usually has one too many and starts making a fool of himself.

children.name: pissed x
children.definition: pissed uk spoken drunk - many people consider this to be an impolite word:say mèm, say bí tỉ
examples: every time she goes to a party she gets pissed.
don’t listen to him - he’s pissed.

children.name: drunken x
children.definition: drunkenwrittena drunken person is drunk and their drunken behaviour shows that they are drunk:say
examples: a couple of drunken sailors were arguing with a policeman outside the bar.
the place was full of noise and drunken shouting.
drunken brawla fight between people who are drunk
many of their beer parties ended in a drunken brawl.
in a drunken stuporalmost unconscious as a result of being drunk
we found him lying by the roadside in a drunken stupor.
drunkenness[u]
she hated morel because of his constant drunkenness and his violent temper.
drunkenly[adv]
he staggered drunkenly toward the door.

children.name: intoxicated x
children.definition: intoxicated formal drunk - use this especially in legal, official, and medical contexts:say
examples: jensen was found guilty of driving while intoxicated.
our policy is not to serve alcohol to anyone who is already intoxicated.
intoxication[u] formal:
he’s already been arrested twice for public intoxication.

children.name: have been drinking u
children.definition: have been drinking use this about sb who you know has been drinking alcohol because they are behaving as if they were drunk or because you can smell alcohol on their breath: đãuống rượu
examples: have you guys been drinking all day?
she answered the door in her bathrobe and i could tell she’d been drinking.

children.name: alcoholic c2
children.definition: alcoholic sb who drinkstoomuchalcohol and cannot stop:người uống nhiều, người nghiện rượu
examples: many alcoholics do not realize that they have a problem until it is too late.
i usually have a drink or two after work, but i don’t think i’m an alcoholic.

children.name: drunk x
children.definition: drunk disapproving sb who is drunk or who often gets drunk - use this especially about someone you see in apublicplace such as a street or a bar:người nghiện rượu
examples: a couple of drunks were passed out on the sidewalk.
i don’t like to take the bus at night. it’s full of drunks and crazy people.

children.name: drinker x
children.definition: drinker sb who often drinks a lot of alcohol:con sâu rượu
examples: he had the watery eyes and swollen nose of a drinker.
i'm not much of a drinker (= i don't drink much alcohol) .
heavy drinkersomeone who regularly drinks a lot of alcohol
paul and jane were both heavy drinkers and spent most of their time in the local bar.
he's aheavy/lightdrinker (= drinks/does not drink a lot of alcohol) .
hard drinkersomeone who regularly drinks a lot of alcohol
he quickly earned the reputation as a hard drinker and hell-raiser.

children.name: have a drink problem x
children.definition: have a drink problemuk /havea drinking problemus  to be unable to stop the habit of drinking too much alcohol, so that it has a bad effect on your life:bị nghiện rượu
examples: my sister has a drink problem but she won’t admit it.
from everything you tell me, it sounds as if your husband may have a drinking problem.

children.name: lush x
children.definition: lush usinformalsb who is often drunk - often usedhumorously:tên bợm rượu
examples: you’ll see her sitting at the bar all day. she’s a real lush.
what are you drinking, you big lush?

children.name: drunkard x
children.definition: drunkard sb who is drunk very often - used especially in literature:người nghiện rượu
examples: they were all drunkards, but arthur was the worst of them all.
unfortunately she had married an incurable drunkard.

children.name: sober up x
children.definition: sober up if sb who has been drunk sobers up, theygraduallybecome less drunk until they are not drunk at all:tỉnh rượu
examples: he didn’t sober up till he’d had a cup of strong coffee.
give her a little time to sober up.
i went for a walk to try to sober up.
i had sobered up by now and felt terrible.
soberup[m]
have a black coffee - that should sober you up!
some coffee should sober you up.

children.name: sober c2
children.definition: sober not drunk:không say
examples: i don’t think i’ve ever seen bill sober.
i’ll drive you home - i think i’m the only one here that’s sober.
sobriety[u] formal the state of being sober:
usthe police said his car had been weaving all over the road, so they pulled him over and gave him a sobriety test .
john had periods of sobriety, but always went back to drinking.

children.name: mellow x
children.definition: mellow pleasantly friendly and ready to talk because you are slightly drunk:ngà ngà say,
examples: she wasn’t drunk yet, but she was feeling nice and mellow and happy.
she poured him another glass of brandy to keep him in a mellow mood.

children.name: tipsy x
children.definition: tipsy informal slightly drunk:hơi say, ngà ngà say
examples: after the second glass of wine i was feeling a little tipsy.
we went out to dinner, got a little tipsy, and ended up at my place.

children.name: merry x
children.definition: merry uk feeling happy and friendly because you are slightly drunk:thấy lâng lâng, phấn khích
examples: we were all very merry by the time the party broke up.
some of the officers got quite merry celebrating our recent victory.

children.name: buzzed x
children.definition: buzzed usspokenfeeling slightly drunk:
examples: this stuff is strong - i’m already a little buzzed.

children.name: blind drunk x
children.definition: blind drunksay mèm, say bí tỉ
examples: every saturday night he came home blind drunk.
don’t give him anything more to drink. he’s already blind drunk.

children.name: roaring drunk x
children.definition: roaring drunk very drunk and very noisy:say ầm ĩ
examples: they were all roaring drunk and kept singing bawdy songs.
they came back from the pub roaring drunk.

children.name: smashed x
children.definition: smashed/ plastered/ trashed spoken informal very drunksay khướt
examples: we went to a nightclub in town last night and got absolutely plastered.
she came home completely smashed at about 2 o'clock this morning.
man, you were so trashed. how much did you have to drink?

children.name: bombed x
children.definition: bombed/ loaded/ wasted us spoken very drunk:say khướt
examples: did you see kim at rob’s party? she was totally wasted.
he’s loaded. somebody better call him a cab.
i was so bombed, i can’t even remember half of what i did.

children.name: paralytic x
children.definition: paralytic/ legless uk spoken extremely drunk:say bí tỉ
examples: don’t give dave any more to drink -- he’s already legless.
the day i got my exam results we went out and got absolutely paralytic.

children.name: get drunk b2
children.definition: get drunk
examples: their idea of a good time is to go out and get drunk.
i can’t remember the last time i got drunk.
she sometimes gets drunk on two glasses of wine.
i just hope they don’t get too drunk and start fighting.

children.name: drown your sorrows x
children.definition: drown your sorrows to drink a lot of alcohol with the purpose of getting drunk, in order to forget your problems:uống rượu giải sầu
examples: after his girlfriend left he spent the evening drowning his sorrows in a local bar.
drown your sorrows in
you can’t just sit around day after day drowning your sorrows in whiskey.

children.name: hit the bottle x
children.definition: hit the bottle informal to start to drink a lot of alcohol regularly, especially in order to forget your problems:mượn rượu bia giải tỏa nỗi buồn
examples: when his wife died he hit the bottle again.
my sister’s been hitting the bottle a lot lately and her work is starting to suffer.

children.name: an occasion when people get drunk
booze-up x
children.definition: booze-up uk informal a party or other occasion where people drink a lot of alcohol:một dịp chè chén say sưa
examples: we usually get together with our friends for a booze-up at christmas.

children.name: drunken x
children.definition: drunkendrunken party/night/orgy etcdisapproving where people drink a lot of alcohol:nơi tụ tạp những người say rượu
examples: the two met at a drunken party in college.
a drunkenbrawl
he came home and fell into a drunkenstupor(= sleep) .

children.name: boozy x
children.definition: boozy especially uk, informal a boozy occasion is one on which people drink a lot of alcohol: say sưa
examples: she’s going for a boozy night out with her friends.
a boozy night out

children.name: able to drink a lot of alcohol
can hold your drink x
children.definition: can hold your drinkuk /can hold your liquor/alcoholus  disapproving if you can hold your drink, you are able to drink a large amount of alcohol without getting drunk:có tửu lượng tốt
examples: he can really hold his drink. i’ve seen him drink seven whiskies and still play a good game of billiards.
debra giggled again - she’d never held her liquor very well.
